4. I returned and a woman was looking at Amber, horrified. She had just arrived for her breakfast and she had seen a young lady - who was alone - spot a turd on the floor, casually walk over and pop it in a lunchbox. Plain as day
3. Me and Arthur were long gone. Amber ran over, picked up the poo and put it in the lunchbox so she could find a bin ASAP. She was mortified

2. I didn't notice the little log fall out of his pyjama shorts leg and I made a beeline for the toilets.

My partner, Amber, saw it and ran over. There were no nearby bins and it was a full cafe.

Amber had a small cardboard lunchbox with some brekky in from the hotel.

1. I can't stop thinking about a person I saw at the airport when we flew home this week...

Arthur did a cheeky poo in his pyjamas (it was an early flight and we'd taken him straight from bed)

I picked him up to run to the loo to change him

Each 'cluster group' could include primary, secondary, special, FE etc or clusters could be matched by sector (eg a primary, EYFS and special cluster and a secondary, FE amd special cluster). Cluster visits could be half days or full days, followed by sharing of docs

Idea:

10 schools up north, 10 in the midlands, 10 down south

Each cluster of 10 visits each other over a term. All planning and curriculum documentation is shared freely
Each cluster of 10 enter a lottery to win the donated ¬£1000

@Headteacherchat Our core monitoring cycle involves SERFs (self evaluation and reporting forms) followed by QA learning walks, Twenty20s, @IRIS_Connect film clubs and teach meets. I'm also really excited to grow our banks of clips on our IRIS Curriculum Groups: https://t.co/uCUH379h3d
@Headteacherchat For example I, as reading lead, will join a reading and / or story session in a different class - from Nursery and our Targeted Mainstream Provision - through to Y6 each week

@Headteacherchat Alongside our monitoring cycle,  we've introduced an extended leadership model, where every member of the SLT and ELT has an additional development day to team teach and collaborate in a different class every week. It should be really exciting and it'll have a huge impact!

@HalilMrT4Real I'm looking at PP in the new year to see, so possibly ü§û With late funding, it's the draft EHCPs coming through really late, then underbanded, then appealed and delayed again. No backdated monies as there isn't an EHCP yet and the finding starts when the doc starts doesn't it?
@HalilMrT4Real ...so not enough to help. Other schools I know with similar SEND have 3 x our PP budget which means more interventions, non-class-based SLT, pastoral support which benefits all

@HalilMrT4Real We've 40% on the SEND register, nearly 9% with EHCPs and every single EHCP has been underdanded (usually 2 bands) and late (10-18 weeks late). I don't know where the missing money in the middle should come from. We're also caught because our PP is only 25%...
Does your school use your Pupil Premium money to cover the gaps with your SEND funding shortfall?

The #ClassroomTours #edutwitter @YouTube channel was created to celebrate uniqueness. It has been so sad to read DMs from a number of people who want to share, but fear the social media rudeness that seems inevitable these days
https://t.co/AdoSA0EEXQ

Full respect to those who think / say "That's different to mine. I wonder why. Maybe I could ask politely for own development or scroll on by and keep my typing to myself"

Twitter character limits can often create rudeness where none was intended. Bear that in mind. Retweets too

@Mr_Minchin @IRIS_Connect @kateowbridge To each their own! We find it works well as a team, but there's a level of buy in required that is led by an understanding and input into the creation of the curriculum and monitoring cycle. It's high challenge, but very high support

So many cracking curriculum debates on here today. For what it's worth, I'd love to hear more of a focus on the underpinning dispositions and skills rather than just the curricular (subject specific) outcomes. Both sides are so important:
https://t.co/fySnKFwJ5e

@Mr_Minchin @IRIS_Connect @kateowbridge For my school, it started off as self-reflection when we removed formal observations of staff. Now it's much bigger than that as we can bank quality assured clips for all staff to refer to on our IRIS Connect curriculum groups. Some details here:
https://t.co/uCUH379h3d

@kateowbridge @Mr_Minchin This, coupled with @IRIS_Connect, means we can lead by example whilst having a frontline understanding of our curriculum areas. It's also hugely supportive in terms of curriculum delivery and behaviour support

@kateowbridge @Mr_Minchin For example I'll join in with / support / co-deliver a reading session in a different class every week. Our maths lead will do the same with maths, writing lead with writing and so on

@kateowbridge @Mr_Minchin We have an SLT and ELT (extended leadership team). Both SLT and ELT, including me, will co-deliver or support a curriculum area they lead on in a different class every week. Following that, we pop via planning to check in

@Mr_Minchin It works best when subject leads work in close collaboration with classroom practitioners, then you can nail the curriculum offer alongside the bespoke delivery in class. Easier said than done to facilitate the time though!

@Mr_Minchin Not in my experience in primary. Even with schemes being brought in, they need to be personalised to fit the school's curriculum model and the needs of each unique class. I do feel that there's less of a demand for individual session plans though

@CatT1970 For best results, take boards down & iron the hessian. Spray glue it on & staple it round the back of the board, then border in wood. It'll last years and years. Alternatively, iron, stretch and staple then border in a nice black for a speedy result. Use pins for work, no staples

@burningoutteach @clairejyaxley @WhistleblowingT Request a copy of your allocated hours / directed time ASAP. You cannot be made to work outside of these stated times

@EdadventuresM @nicolajharvey @redgierob ...as they'll be waiting on an answer. After 24 hours, they'll know they aren't first choice (happened to me!). They may also move to something else and you'll miss someone potentially fab

@EdadventuresM @nicolajharvey @redgierob Absolutely, I just mean it'll get to a cutoff point where if you wait any longer, it could skew the school's view of the situation. I've been asked to wait a day or 2 before, outside of that it's messy as if the person then turns it down it's unfair on other candidates...
@nicolajharvey @EdadventuresM @redgierob Good luck!

@nicolajharvey @EdadventuresM @redgierob Schools should, IMO, tell candidates that they'll know within 24 (maybe 48) hours of the interview etc if they'll be appointed. That way you're protected both ways. If the school wouldn't wait a day for me, then I'd have some big questions to ask!
@EdadventuresM @nicolajharvey @redgierob Absolutely. Honesty is key!

@nicolajharvey @EdadventuresM @redgierob Once offered, you can request some time to consider it before accepting - for example you might be relocating or have other jobs you're waiting on. 24 hours is fine, 48 at a push. Any longer and it gets messy
@burningoutteach @WhistleblowingT Union up!
@WhistleblowingT Doesn't let you leave? Refer to 1265 hours and directed time. Speak to your union immediately, that's not OK in the slightest

@EdRoundtables @dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor @keith_campion Absolutely agree. I tend to give tours of 45 mins to an hour per person so we can see loads and talk a lot. We speak to kids, pop into classrooms, chat to staff and talk through policies and expectations in detail. Definitely going to watch when I get chance!

@keith_campion @dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor Agreed, but it's surprising what you can find out with a wee bit if digging. Systems and policies are easy. Asking to chat to children and staff on your visit, if you can do one. Maybe chat with parents/carers too if possible. HR cases and dismissals sometimes even
@keith_campion @dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor I say naively, but they were also decisions made in desperation!

@keith_campion @dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor And I say this from experience. I have naively jumped from frying pan to fire more than once and it nearly broke me, both professionally and personally. That's why I'll keep advising people to do as much due diligence as they have capacity to!
https://t.co/H6AnGN8Za6

@keith_campion @dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor That can definitely happen. Also, most often in my experience, it's a misalignment of values and/or morals. For example behaviour management systems, teaching styles, expectations of staff/children, inclusion differences. A lot of this could be unpicked in advance
@MeggittPhillips @IsabelleFollath Brilliant news!

@InclusionUAE @AtHomeOnTheMoor @keith_campion Absolutely appreciate it's not always possible, but in those situations I'd look at the website, Ofsted report (if it's recent), social media and LA / Trust. A phone call to ask any questions too. I'm just saying there's no harm in doing these things
@dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor @keith_campion IMO it's better to work supply and find the school you love than jump into one that could really hurt you

@dumond_ed @AtHomeOnTheMoor @keith_campion With respect, I disagree. A visit gives you at least an idea and it's a good time to ask questions. Also, a large reason for the number of teachers - especially NQTs - dropping out of the profession is due to finding the wrong school
@MrsPLearnsToo Understandably frustrating. Persevere and / or try supply to build up experience and find somewhere you really like

8. And if you are successfully shortlisted, give yourself time to plan out your lessons (or whatever tasks you need to do) in as much advance as you can. It's so obvious when there's been a lot of care and attention put in!
7. Give yourself time to write a proper application. Don't just use a template from university and don't rush it. If you want this role, then make it clear that you've put in time and thought

@soundofsugar @TarverTeach @MrTs_NQTs You say it's a red flag, but I couldn't tell you a single school that wouldn't observe a teacher prior to appointment. The process has to be robust and fully quality assured. I wouldn't observe a senior leader, unless they were leading on teaching and learning

@soundofsugar @TarverTeach @MrTs_NQTs You won't have permission to talk to people they work with, only a written reference. That might gave been an agreed reference, plus it doesn't show the teacher cam teach the kids in your school context
6. Check with your references before including their details. I get heaps of reference requests and I'm only asked directly for a handful! A reference takes a decent amount of time to complete
5. Proofread! Have a friend or family member proofread it too. Don't send an application filled with typos, grammatical errors or, heaven forbid, the wrong school name thrown in
4. Sell your vision and values and how they align with those of the school. Use common language with the school values and overcommunicate your uniqueness and what additionally you bring to the team
3. Fill out the application forms properly. Don't send stuff you're not asked to. Don't miss important bits out. Don't send a CV on its own when there's a specific template to use
2. Always visit first if you can. This gives you insight that the website won't. You'll also get chance to pre-interview your potential employed and see how you feel about the school

1. After shortlisting many applicants down to a small group, I'm left with some reflections. I hope they're useful (thread)

1. Personalise your application to the school. We need to know that you know us and that you've taken the time to find out or visit
@TarverTeach @MrTs_NQTs I'd take it just in case

@soundofsugar @TarverTeach @MrTs_NQTs How else will interviewers know what you're like as a teacher, other than your word? I do prefer the idea of observing people where they presently work if possible, though no chance in our latest recruitment phase

@keith_campion Also, we can use our language skills to quality assure our decoding. That can't be done for alien words. I suppose you could argue that the phonics test is purely decoding, but IMO it's important to strike a balance

@keith_campion Personally, I'd rather see fewer 'alien' words and more broken apart parts of polysyllabic words so they're more applicable. Alien words are very confusing for children when a lot of our language is alien to many at that age - why add confusion!

@keith_campion Phonics in general, or the task pictured? Phonics is necessary to decode, so it's a useful part of a reading toolkit. The task looks like it's trying to acclimatise children to the screening test formats, so arguably will benefit assessment but not necessarily understanding

@thatteacherguy_ @Headteacherchat @PaulGarvey4 That's the problem with a binary survey. I feel we're both saying "there's a better middle ground here"!
@thatteacherguy_ @Headteacherchat It was a fairly vague question and didn't specify, but almost everyone has read it as 'once qualified'. Possibly me looking at the discussion awkwardly - I tend to!

@thatteacherguy_ @Headteacherchat In fact, being up to speed with other phases is critical as a subject lead and as SLT. I see no harm in swap days, Twenty20s, teach meets, cross-phase moderation and film clubs. See some of those here, inspired by @PaulGarvey4's Talk for Teaching: 
https://t.co/hogaA70E2M

@thatteacherguy_ @Headteacherchat It's pretty easy to fit into teacher training logistically. At the end of the day, I believe in putting people where they perform best and where they feel happiest. I also feel this should be balanced with opportunities to explore and observe in other phases

@thatteacherguy_ @Headteacherchat I believe there's just better amplifying of more diverse voices - by many measures of diversity - rather than a KS2 dominated narrative, which has been my experience in the past

@thatteacherguy_ @Headteacherchat I'm not sure I see the cliche, but I agree that all years are equally important. I do see EYFS spoken down to and marginalised regularly on social media and in previous schools though. IMO EYFS and special are the most misunderstood sectors

@kimturner70 @WhistleblowingT Secret recordings are dangerous territory. It's legal if it's just for you, but you couldn't share it or use it as evidence for anything. Better to have someone impartial present to minute the meeting and have all sign and agree to the minutes taken, then it's all above board

@VoicesofSEND @mc22133 @kimturner70 @WhistleblowingT Correct, but you couldn't legally share it with your union or at tribunal. Better to have an impartial colleague or union rep there to minute the meeting then have all who were present read and sign the minutes when the confirm they are accurate
@fidsta77 @mrs_darl @SlatteryMr @TJGriffiths @MissS_Kimble @_Nicola_M_ @ArticuLaight Phwoar!

@WhistleblowingT Also, you can contest fake or inaccurate minutes. Make sure you do so in writing so it's all logged. I would recommend asking that all minutes taken are sent for checking and agreeing following meetings (where your union are present) so you can approve or amend before agreeing
@TeachRepeat @PieCorbett @_Reading_Rocks_ @MichaelRosenYes @kwamealexander @SmritiPH @dc_litchfield Brilliant! Happy reading!
@WhistleblowingT By having union representation in any formal meeting and whistleblowing / complaints to the CoG / Trust/ LA in line with policy

@3mummysl My issue with alien words is that they're devoid of context. Chunking a syllable is fine as it makes sense when constructed into a word. No need for pseudo words and children can't connect them to their wider reading and vocab to check if they're right
@MrP_AHT Oh damn. Should I delete and start again?

Does phonics work for all pupils? Absolutely not, but it is a tool that helps many to take steps on their reading journeys. Should we hammer struggling readers with more phonics? Again, it's one tool amongst many. This discussion is deeper than the do or don't test fall out

Has anyone ever delivered a screening test and thought 'blimey, this child can / can't read?!' No, because we know our kids. Has anyone ever pushed kids to score 32/40 when they struggle with early resding? I'm sure they have. Does phonics make a reader? No, it's one tool of many

IMO the teaching of phonics is fine alongside lots of talk & reading for pleasure. I believe that testing children in Y1 is unnecessary. 'Alien' words can be confusing for pupils as they are just starting to grasp English, but I'm OK with them being used logically (eg syllables)
@philearle Blimey, how did I miss this?!
